wrong PR with redundant commits
pull request to a wrong branch, sorry.
Did you test the cuda version of prelu?
Pls try to run test again to check if any numeric errors in test cases.

To work on this PR, pls fetch this branch and get the cnmem by

```
git submodule init
git submodule update
```

Merged.
TODO:
1. replace hard-code path
2. remove example_xx.py files in python

The Reader class may need a SeekToStart() function for repeating the reading over the dataset multiple times.
Or adding a flag to the read function, e.g., auto_repeat, if true, then seek to first automatically when reaching the file end.

Could you pls update test/singa/test_tensor_math.cc to include the test for opencl functions..
We need to know how to use opencl devices, any differences with cuda devices when using the Tensor class.
Thanks.

Replacing this request with another one on the dev branch: 

https://github.com/apache/incubator-singa/pull/208

Thanks for the PR.
I think it would be better to convert previous docs one by one instead of all in one PR.
We can add docs for dev branch (v1.0) at first, and then convert docs for v0.3 (after merging dev and master).

make: **\* [html] Error 1

I just tested the time for running with 2gpu and 1gpu (140epochs in total):
2gpus 14 min
1gpu 8 min
Need to figure out the reasons.

Some minor problems:
1. the logo of singa is too large. may consider put the logo and apache logo horizontally. 
2. the TOC of English includes Dependencies and Instructions which are subsections of Installation. But Installation is not listed in the TOC, which should be at the same level as Introduction.

Thanks.

It seems copying gradient to cpu and doing sum operation on cpu costs time.
Following is time cost in each part when train on one batch:

Forward time: 0.000988s  (on gpu)
Backward time: 0.001189s (on gpu)
Update time: 0.014970s (on cpu)

In update time:
Copy gradient to cpu 0.004150s
add gradient 0.001950s
average gradient 0.000852s
copy parameter to cpu 0.000891s
optimization algorithm on cpu 0.006571s
copy updated parameter back to gpu 0.000556s

commits from other branches are mixed into this branch.
pls update the commit msg (title and content).

The problem is caused by using two different protobuf libs.
Please make sure you use the same version of protobuf for compiling your own code and the singa code.
Ok. I think the problem is fixed now and the PR can be merged. Thank you.

Please note also that [Doxyfile](https://github.com/apache/incubator-singa/blob/master/doc/Doxyfile) can not have comments and must have Apache license header. See http://www.apache.org/legal/resolved.html

> Can we use Doxygen-generated config files?

> As long as the generated comments are removed from the Doxygen-generated files, these files may be used. 

And see for example: https://github.com/apache/avro/blob/master/lang/c%2B%2B/Doxyfile

The Tinydir license can be safely removed from SINGA, because it is already included in [tinydir.h](https://github.com/apache/incubator-singa/blob/master/include/singa/utils/tinydir.h) .

See https://github.com/cxong/tinydir :
> if you use tinydir you can comply by including tinydir.h
I checked the notebooks and they work fine. I made small fixes and merged all changes in one commit.
It would be safe to mention the license of tinydir.h in the the LICENSE file together with others.

Can you please check now if the PR is ok? 

I still think the license can be further improved, but at least we improved some issues in this PR.

Please check again.
You can add new commits (no need to overwrite the existing commits).

I generated the singa-cpp/python-singa.deb using ubuntu:14.04 docker image.
but it cannot be installed on aws with ubuntu14.04. 
the error log is attached.
[out.txt](https://github.com/apache/incubator-singa/files/782297/out.txt)

To install python-singa.deb on Ubuntu 14:04 :
```
 apt-get update && apt-get install ca-certificates
 dpkg -i ./python-singa.deb 
 apt-get install -f
```
To build  python-singa.deb on Ubuntu 14:04 :

```
apt-get update && apt-get install git cmake  python2.7-dev python-pip python-numpy libprotobuf-dev libopenblas-dev protobuf-compiler libpcre3 libpcre3-dev wget
wget https://launchpad.net/ubuntu/+archive/primary/+files/swig_3.0.2.orig.tar.gz
tar -xvzf ./swig_3.0.2.orig.tar.gz 
cd swig-3.0.2/
./configure 
make
make install
cd ..
git clone https://github.com/moazreyad/incubator-singa.git
cd incubator-singa/
git checkout SINGA-274
./tool/debian/build.sh -b -p
```
This PR can be closed because [PR 309](https://github.com/apache/incubator-singa/pull/309) provides better solution with CPack.

Avoid using apt-get and use dpkg instead:

```
apt-get update && apt-get install ca-certificates
dpkg -i ./python-singa-cuda-1.1.0.deb 
apt-get install -f
```

This is normal, just ignore the errors and do 

`apt-get install -f`

I see that [line 193 in CMakeLists.txt](https://github.com/apache/incubator-singa/blob/master/CMakeLists.txt#L193) is commented:

`SET(CPACK_DEBIAN_PACKAGE_CONTROL_EXTRA "${PROJECT_SOURCE_DIR}/tool/debian/postinst;${PROJECT_SOURCE_DIR}/tool/debian/postrm" )`

And also the folder `tool/debian` is deleted. 

Why did you remove this line and folder? CPack for python-singa will not work without them.

when we execute `make install`, cmake would execute

    python setup.py install

to install python files.
Hence, we don't need the postins and postrm files.
I passed the test for the CPU version. but it failed for the gpu version.

The packaging scenario is different from the` make install` scenario. In ` make install`, the code is built and installed on the same machine. In the packaging scenario, the code is built on one machine and installed on another. It is true that postins and postrm are not needed if the code is built and installed on the same machine, but they are needed for the Debian packaging. 

`Make` will not be called when installing the binary Debian package with apt (dpkg) and may be `make` will not be available at all on the target machine.

The test will pass for make install, but all python packaging with CPack will not work. The Debian package will not work both for CPU and GPU because at least the `postins` file is needed.

previously, you copied the python files into the prefix folder https://github.com/moazreyad/incubator-singa/blob/cde701abd3ae295505600820708d79d2e471438a/CMakeLists.txt#L171
which is equivalent to `make install`. But we need to add new lines to if the python folder has changes later.
In addition, `make install` would execute `python setup.py install`, which is equivalent to `pip install .` in postinst. 
hence, there is no need for postinst as long as we execute

    cmake ..
    make install
    make package

The process of CPack is make > make install > execute install scripts > pack all files to bundle (from [here](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/18722972/prevent-install-code-script-during-cpack-package-generation)). This is executed on the building machine, not on the target machine. 

On the target machine, the package manager (apt) have to do equivalent operations to the `make install `using shell scripts (`postinst`) and copy commands (`INSTALL FILES `and` INSTALL DIRECTORY`). This is why it is required also to copy the python files. If we do not copy them, they will not be found in the target machine if it is different from the build machine which is the expected scenario for the package.

Note: It is better to use `pip install .` than` python setup.py `in the `postinst`.

I understand that the building machine and the targeting machines are different.
If the python-singa.deb contains all files (including libsinga.so, the headers and python scripts copied by make install, excluding those from apt-get and pip install), then it should be able to put them into the correct folder of the target machine. 
For the libs from apt-get, it also can install them as they are configured in cpack. 
But for the external python packages, it may not be able to install them automatically. Hence we need a postinst file to just install those files?

`postinst` is needed to install the SINGA python module (and its dependent external python packages) on the target machine. This is required to run SINGA from python. Otherwise, the user must install it manually.

`postrm` is needed for cleaning if the package is uninstalled. This is required if the user wants to remove the package and install another version. Otherwise, the user must deleted the files manually.

Note: python-singa.deb will not contain all the files if the (INSTALL FILES and INSTALL DIRECTORY) are removed.

I think https://github.com/apache/incubator-singa/blob/master/CMakeLists.txt#L172 is equivalent to https://github.com/moazreyad/incubator-singa/blob/cde701abd3ae295505600820708d79d2e471438a/CMakeLists.txt#L171. Both will copy the python scripts into the prefix folder.

The first one will copy the scripts into the prefix folder in **the build machine**. The second one will copy the scripts into the folder in **the target machine** (and also in the build machine again).

The first one has no effect on the `make package` command. It will be executed, but without any useful effect. It can be removed safely and` make package` will still work fine. (But the `make install` will fail). This is why both are needed.

how can the second one be executed on the target machine?
It is just a cmake command, which copies the files into the prefix folder in the build machine.
the first one also copies the files into the prefix folder. hence, I think they are equivalent.

I think cpack just compress all files in a folder into .deb. apt-get would decompress the files and put them into the system folder, and install some dependent libs, and execute postinst.

I didn't say the second one will be **executed** on the target machine. The second one **will copy the files in the target machine**. This is because INSTALL is not only a cmake command, it is also a cpack command. If the file is not in the INSTALL command, cpack will not copy it. 

In summary: 

the first one is redundant to` make package` but necessary for `make install`
the second one is  redundant to `make install `but necessary for `make package`

So please keep both of them if we want both `make install` and` make package `to work.

sorry. I am still confused about "This is because INSTALL is not only a cmake command, it is also a cpack command. If the file is not in the INSTALL command, cpack will not **copy** it." Do you mean copy it on the target machine?

INSTALL only works on the build machine. I understand that without INSTALL, cpack does not copy those files into the prefix folder. But it doesn't matter, as the first command would copy those files into the prefix folder.

I understand that cpack a tool which is used during generating .deb file.  apt-get is another tool which decompress .deb file and put the files into the system folder. cpack would not be involved when we do `apt-get install ./python-singa.deb`.

As long as all files are in the .deb file, apt-get should put them into the correct folders.

Yes, I mean it will copy the files to the target machine. CPack will archive the files in the Debian package and the dpkg command on the target machine will unarchive them.

The Debian package must contain setup.py, _singa_wrap.so, singa_wrap.py and the two directories DIRECTORY ${PROJECT_SOURCE_DIR}/python , ${CMAKE_BINARY_DIR}/python/singa/proto to be able to install the SINGA python module. 

If you removed the lines:

```
INSTALL(DIRECTORY ${PROJECT_SOURCE_DIR}/python 
	DESTINATION ${CMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX}/lib/singa)	

INSTALL(FILES ${CMAKE_BINARY_DIR}/python/setup.py 
	DESTINATION ${CMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX}/lib/singa/python)
INSTALL(FILES ${CMAKE_BINARY_DIR}/python/singa/singa_wrap.py
	DESTINATION ${CMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX}/lib/singa/python/singa)
INSTALL(FILES ${CMAKE_BINARY_DIR}/python/singa/_singa_wrap.so
	DESTINATION ${CMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX}/lib/singa/python/singa)
INSTALL(DIRECTORY ${CMAKE_BINARY_DIR}/python/singa/proto
	DESTINATION ${CMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX}/lib/singa/python/singa)
```
Then these files will not be in the debian package generated by make package:
```
ar x python-singa-1.1.0.deb
tar -xvzf data.tar.gz | grep setup.py
```
will show nothing, because setup.py is not in the package.

OK. I will try it.

If you want to install the files only with CPack to avoid redundancy during make install, then please try to use these lines:

```
IF (USE_PYTHON)
	INSTALL(FILES ${CMAKE_BINARY_DIR}/python/setup.py 
		DESTINATION ${CMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX}/lib/singa/python
		COMPONENT PySinga)
	INSTALL(FILES ${CMAKE_BINARY_DIR}/python/singa/singa_wrap.py
		DESTINATION ${CMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX}/lib/singa/python/singa
		COMPONENT PySinga)
	INSTALL(FILES ${CMAKE_BINARY_DIR}/python/singa/_singa_wrap.so
		DESTINATION ${CMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX}/lib/singa/python/singa
		COMPONENT PySinga)
	INSTALL(DIRECTORY ${PROJECT_SOURCE_DIR}/python 
		DESTINATION ${CMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX}/lib/singa
		COMPONENT PySinga)	
	INSTALL(DIRECTORY ${CMAKE_BINARY_DIR}/python/singa/proto
		DESTINATION ${CMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX}/lib/singa/python/singa
		COMPONENT PySinga)	
	SET(CPACK_COMPONENTS_ALL PySinga)
ENDIF()
```

I used the `future` library and add the `PYTHON2 ` option to `cmake `.

Now both Python 2 and 3 are supported.

This upgrade supports both Python 2 and Python 3, with and without CUDA/cuDNN GPU support.

The default is Python 3. To build the Python 2 version, set the PYTHON2 option in cmake:

```
cmake -DPYTHON2=YES 
```

To use Python 3, it is required to have SWIG 3.0.10. It is available in Ubuntu >17.04. For other operating systems, you may install it manually or from the Ubuntu 17.04 repository:
```
echo "deb http://archive.ubuntu.com/ubuntu zesty universe" >> /etc/apt/sources.list
apt-get update && apt-get install swig3.0
```
By the way, I faced this problem while upgrading to Python 3 and solved it with this [PR](https://github.com/apache/incubator-singa/pull/323/commits/2e93f327c713ab288b94f286d60e2878286acf02):

I have passed the test for conda building.
Shall we use  python 2 as the default option and use -DPYTHON3=ON for python 3?
It seems that package x is for python2 by default, and x-python3 is for python 3.

The support of Python 2 will end in 2020 (See https://pythonclock.org), so I would say it is better to use Python 3 as the default building option and encourage users to avoid building new solutions with Python 2 unless there is a good reason. 

But this is just a design choice. If most of the current users will build with Python 2, then you can set it as the default for now.

In any case, the naming of the package is independent of which version is the default.
